title: VC Daily: Will Infrastructure Law Provide a Boost for Startups?
text:
Investor David Wilkens wrote that late-stage companies that raised at high valuations will likely be hurt, but that seed-stage startups have the potential to grow faster than inflation. "Perversely and for this reason you may see more money flood seed stage resulting in a flattening of the valuation curve that has seen growth stage multiples expand faster than seed stage over the last couple years."

Don Butler, managing director at Thomvest Ventures, wrote that while the valuation bubble may pop because of rising inflation, the large amounts of capital committed to venture funds by LPs will create "a floor on how far valuations can drop."

This week's question: President Biden finally signed the infrastructure bill into law. What direct impact will the law, and the $1 trillion in government spending associated with it, have on startups?

Please email responses to marc.vartabedian@wsj.com

And now on to the news...

Top News

Paytm stumbles in debut. Shares in the owner of Indian mobile-payments company Paytm fell sharply on their first day of trading, after it sold about $2.5 billion of stock in the country's largest initial public offering, The Wall Street Journal reports. Stock in One97 Communications Ltd. dropped 27% from its IPO price of 2,150 rupees, the equivalent of $28.95, to close Thursday at 1,564 rupees. The shares were prevented from falling further by a halt in trading before the end of the session.

"For the time being, the stock has disappointed," said Alok Churiwala, managing director at Churiwala Securities Pvt. Ltd., a brokerage firm in Mumbai. He said the selling on Thursday was driven by individual investors who had subscribed to the IPO hoping to benefit from gains on listing day, but who instead quickly exited their positions once the shares began falling.

Paytm is one of India's largest digital-payments and financial-services platforms, serving more than 333 million consumers. Its big backers include SoftBank Group Corp.'s Vision Fund, Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and Ant Group Co., Jack Ma's Chinese financial-technology giant.

900

The number of stores CVS Health Corp. said it will close over the next three years, while adding more health services at remaining locations. (WSJ)

ADM Buys Stake in Startup Farmers Business Network

Archer Daniels Midland Co. invested in Farmers Business Network and announced a partnership with the agricultural-technology firm aimed at making it easier to track the carbon footprint of crops from the planting stage, the Journal reports. This latest fundraising round valued Farmers Business Network at $3.9 billion, a spokesperson for the company said. ADM said it made an equity investment through its venture-capital arm, but declined to disclose the size. Fidelity Investments Inc. is the lead investor in this round. Others include LK Advisers Ltd, Colle Capital Partners, Walleye Capital LLC and Tudor Investment Corp. Investors from previous rounds, including BlackRock Inc., DBL Partners and Temasek Capital Management Pte Ltd., participated in the latest fundraising.

Mass PRIM Puts $1 Billion Into Program to Cultivate Diverse Managers

Massachusetts is devoting some serious money to develop a cadre of small or recently-established diverse investment-management firms, WSJ Pro reports. The Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board plans to allocate $1 billion over the next two years to its new emerging diverse-managers program, according to David Gurtz, Mass PRIM's deputy chief investment officer and its director of public markets. The effort is designed to help the $98.5 billion public pension system reach its diversity goals. Under a state law passed earlier this year, at least 20% of Mass PRIM's investment managers are expected to be diverse, according to documents presented at a public meeting of the Board's investment committee on Tuesday. Mr. Gurtz cited gender, race and disability as measures of diversity.

Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon Invest in Spanx

Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon and Bumble Inc. founder Whitney Wolfe Herd have invested in Spanx Inc., as Blackstone Inc. completed its majority investment valuing the women's shapewear brand at $1.2 billion. Spanx announced the new slate of celebrity investors, which also include investment funds Able Partners and G9 Ventures founded by Amy Griffin, on Thursday.

Industry News

Funds

Fort Ross Ventures held the first $100 million close of its new late-stage fund, which has a target of $200 million. The fund will focus in Series D or later rounds across fintech, cloud technologies, AI/machine learning, business process automation services, edtech, foodtech and tech-enabled businesses located in the U.S., Israel and Europe. The firm, with offices in Menlo Park, Calif., and Tel Aviv, recently participated in a $100 million funding round for digital life insurance company Ladder Life.

People

Austin, Texas-based Next Coast Ventures named Scott Miller as the firm's newest venture partner. He was most recently co-founder and vice president of products at TrustRadius.

Seeq Corp., a provider of manufacturing and Industrial Internet of Things advanced analytics software, named Lisa J. Graham as the company's new chief executive. She was previously chief operating officer and vice president of analytics engineering at Seeq. Before joining the company, Ms. Graham was chief executive and founder of Alkemy Innovation. In addition to the CEO appointment, Seeq added Ashley Kramer, chief product officer and chief marketing officer at Sisense, to the company's board. Seattle-based Seeq is backed by investors including Insight Partners, Altira Group, Chevron Technology Ventures, Cisco Investments, Saudi Aramco Energy Ventures and Second Avenue Partners.

Enterprise networking software provider Pica8 appointed Brad Bullington to the post of chief executive, replacing James Liao, who will transition to chief technology officer. Mr. Bullington co-founded Q6 Capital, and was previously at Bridgelux, Seagate and Maxtor. Palo Alto, Calif.-based Pica8 is backed by WI Harper Group, Aspiro Capital Management, Vantage Point Ventures and others.

Booster, an energy delivery service for fleets, promoted Jason Godley to president, and appointed Amy O'Neil as chief operating officer and Adrian Agostini as chief revenue officer. Mr. Godley was previously chief financial officer and COO at the company. Ms. O'Neil previously held leadership roles with Hana, Restaurant Technologies and Caribou Coffee Co. Mr. Agostini held positions at Amazon.com, Oracle and UberEats. Booster has raised more than $108 million in funding from Invus Opportunities, Conversion Capital, Enterprise Holdings Ventures, Madrona Venture Group, Maveron, Perot Jain and others.

Exits

AgTech startup Fieldin acquired agricultural autonomous driving company Midnight Robotics for an undisclosed amount. In September, San Jose, Calif.-based Fieldin said it closed a $30 million Series B round from Fortissimo Capital, Zeev Ventures, ICON Accelerator, Maor Investments and Akkadian Ventures.

Papaya Global, a payroll and payment-management platform, acquired remote work connectivity platform NickNack for an undisclosed sum. Tel Aviv-based Papaya Global recently scored a $250 million Series D round at a $3.7 billion valuation from investors including Insight Partners, Tiger Global Management, Greenoaks Capital, IVP, Scale Venture Partners and Bessemer Venture Partners.

Snackpass, a social ordering platform for restaurants, closed the purchase of Sleek, which offers a priority lane experience for ordering food at venues such as music festivals and stadiums. Terms weren't disclosed. San Francisco-based Snackpass said it landed $70 million in Series B funding in June from Craft Ventures, Andreessen Horowitz, General Catalyst and Y Combinator.

New Money

Formstack, a Fishers, Ind.-based workplace-productivity platform, raised a $425 million growth investment led by Silversmith Capital Partners and PSG. Silversmith's Jim Quagliaroli and PSG's Andrew Heim will join the company's board.

Facily, a Säo Paulo-based social-commerce platform, grabbed $250 million in Series D funding from investors including DX Ventures, Delivery Hero, Citius and Tru Arrow Partners.

ConsenSys, a Brooklyn, N.Y.-based blockchain software technology provider, closed a $200 million investment, bringing the company's valuation up to $3.2 billion. Investors in the round included Marshall Wace, ParaFi Capital, Think Investments, Dragonfly Capital, Electric Capital, DeFiance Capital, Coinbase Ventures and HSBC.

Grammarly Inc., a San Francisco-based digital writing assistant, scored more than $200 million in new funding at a $13 billion valuation. New investors including Baillie Gifford and funds and accounts managed by BlackRock were joined by previous backer General Catalyst in the round.

CloudWalk Inc., a São Paulo-based payment-technology network, picked up a $150 million Series C round at a post-money valuation of $2.15 billion. Lead investor Coatue Management was joined by DST Global, A-Star Partners, The Hive Brazil, Plug and Play Ventures, Valor Capital Group and others in the funding.

GaN Systems, a Canadian power semiconductor developer, landed $150 million in growth capital. Fidelity Investments led the funding, which saw participation from Vitesco Technologies, BMW i Ventures and others.

Expel Inc., a Herndon, Va.-based managed detection and response provider, secured $140.3 million in Series E financing co-led by CapitalG and Paladin Capital Group at a valuation of more than $1 billion. New investors Cisco Investments and March Capital also contributed to the round, alongside existing backers Index Ventures, Scale Venture Partners and Greycroft.

EasyHealth, a Beverly Hills, Calif.-based startup seeking to improve health outcomes for Medicare members by connecting coverage and care, raised $135 million in equity and debt funding. Anthemis Group and QED Investors co-led the round, which included additional support from Victory Park Capital, Nationwide Ventures, Healthy Ventures, Brewer Lane Ventures and Operator Partners.

Netlify, San Francisco-based collaborative web development platform, nabbed $105 million in Series D funding, valuing the company at $2 billion. Led by Bessemer Venture Partners, the round included participation from Andreessen Horowitz, BOND, EQT Ventures, Kleiner Perkins, Mango Capital and Menlo Ventures. Bessemer's Mary D'Onofrio and a16z's Martin Casado, along with Elena Verna, will join Netlify's board.

Airwallex, an Australian cross-border payments startup, added $100 million in Series E1 funding, just a few weeks after raising a $200 million Series E round. The new investment, which gives the company a $5.5 billion valuation, was led by Lone Pine Capital, and included participation from 1835i Ventures and Sequoia Capital China.

Gradiant, a cleantech water project developer headquartered in Woburn, Mass., and Singapore, raised over $100 million in an oversubscribed Series C round led by Warburg Pincus and Schlumberger New Energy.

Kandji Inc., a San Diego-based Apple device management and security provider, collected $100 million in Series C funding. Tiger Global Management led the investment, which included contributions from Frontline Ventures, First Round Capital, Greycroft, Felicis Ventures, The Spruce House Partnership, B Capital Group, SVB Capital and Okta Ventures.

Place Inc., a Bellingham, Wash.-based real-estate technology platform, fetched $100 million in Series A funding, giving the company a valuation of more than $1 billion. The growth equity business within Goldman Sachs Asset Management led the investment, which included participation from 3L Capital.

Tech News

Nike launches virtual play place on Roblox

Instagram's effects on children are being investigated by a coalition of states

Alibaba cuts growth forecast on slower consumption, tough competition

China Evergrande to shed stake in Tencent-backed venture for $273 million

An antidote to inflation? ‘Buy nothing' groups gain popularity
